1. Burial customs: Sephardi Jews traditionally bury their dead in a simple shroud or plain wooden casket, while Ashkenazi Jews use a more elaborate coffin, sometimes adorned with symbols or inscriptions.

2. Grave orientation: Sephardi Jews typically face the body towards Jerusalem or Mecca, while Ashkenazi Jews face the body towards the east.

3. Timing of burials: Sephardi Jews generally bury their dead as soon as possible after death, while Ashkenazi Jews may wait longer to allow for family members to travel and attend the funeral.

4. Preparation of the body: Sephardi Jews usually do not embalm or dress the body, while Ashkenazi Jews may embalm and dress the body in traditional burial clothes.

5. Mourning customs: Sephardi Jews observe a seven-day mourning period (shiva), while Ashkenazi Jews observe a seven-day mourning period followed by an additional 30-day period of mourning (shloshim).
